messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

The failing test `org.apache.commons.lang.time.FastDateFormatTest.test_changeDefault_Locale_DateInstance()` is in the `FastDateFormat` class. 

Next, I will retrieve the methods covered by failing tests for the `FastDateFormat` class. I will call the `get_failing_tests_covered_methods_for_class` function with the class name `org.apache.commons.lang.time.FastDateFormat`.

messages.name: get_failing_tests_covered_methods_for_class
messages.content: [".parsePattern()", ".Pair.Pair(java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object)", ".Pair.hashCode()", ".TimeZoneNameRule.TimeZoneNameRule(java.util.TimeZone, boolean, java.util.Locale, int)", ".TimeZoneNameRule.estimateLength()", ".Pair.equals(java.lang.Object)", ".getDateInstance(int)", ".getDateInstance(int, java.util.TimeZone, java.util.Locale)", ".getDateTimeInstance(int, int)", ".getDateTimeInstance(int, int, java.util.Locale)", ".getDateTimeInstance(int, int, java.util.TimeZone, java.util.Locale)", ".UnpaddedNumberField.UnpaddedNumberField(int)", ".UnpaddedNumberField.estimateLength()", ".selectNumberRule(int, int)", ".getLocale()", ".TwelveHourField.TwelveHourField(org.apache.commons.lang.time.FastDateFormat.NumberRule)", ".TwelveHourField.estimateLength()", ".getDateInstance(int, java.util.Locale)", ".StringLiteral.StringLiteral(java.lang.String)", ".StringLiteral.estimateLength()", ".TextField.TextField(int, java.lang.String[])", ".TextField.estimateLength()", ".PaddedNumberField.PaddedNumberField(int, int)", ".PaddedNumberField.estimateLength()", ".CharacterLiteral.CharacterLiteral(char)", ".CharacterLiteral.estimateLength()", ".getInstance(java.lang.String, java.util.TimeZone, java.util.Locale)", ".FastDateFormat(java.lang.String, java.util.TimeZone, java.util.Locale)", ".init()", ".parseToken(java.lang.String, int[])", ".hashCode()", ".TwoDigitNumberField.TwoDigitNumberField(int)", ".TwoDigitNumberField.estimateLength()"]

The failing test covers multiple methods in the `FastDateFormat` class. Here are some of the methods covered by failing tests:
- `.selectNumberRule(int, int)`
- `.getLocale()`
- `.getInstance(java.lang.String, java.util.TimeZone, java.util.Locale)`
- `.FastDateFormat(java.lang.String, java.util.TimeZone, java.util.Locale)`
- `.init()`

Next, I will retrieve the code snippets for these methods to better understand the implementation details.

messages.name: get_code_snippet

messages.content:
The `selectNumberRule` method in the `FastDateFormat` class determines which `NumberRule` to use based on the field and padding values. Different `NumberRule` implementations are returned based on the padding value.

Next, I will retrieve the code snippet for the `.getLocale()` method.

The `getLocale` method in the `FastDateFormat` class simply returns the `mLocale`.

Next, I will retrieve the code snippet for the `getInstance` method in the `FastDateFormat` class.

messages.name: get_code_snippet

messages.content:
The `getInstance` method in the `FastDateFormat` class is a static synchronized method that returns an instance of `FastDateFormat` based on the provided pattern, timezone, and locale. The method uses a cache (`cInstanceCache`) to store and retrieve instances of `FastDateFormat`.

Next, I will retrieve the code snippet for the `FastDateFormat` constructor.

messages.name: get_code_snippet

messages.content:
The constructor of `FastDateFormat` in the `FastDateFormat` class initializes the `mPattern`, `mTimeZone`, and `mLocale` fields based on the provided pattern, timezone, and locale values. If the timezone or locale is not provided, it falls back to the default values (`TimeZone.getDefault()` and `Locale.getDefault()`).

Given this information about the methods and their implementations, it seems that the issue in the failing test may be related to the handling of the default locale in the `FastDateFormat` class. The method `getInstance` seems to set the `mLocale` field based on the provided locale, but there may be an issue with how it handles the default locale when none is provided.

Here are the methods that could be the best locations to be fixed based on the analysis:
- `org.apache.commons.lang.time.FastDateFormat.getInstance(java.lang.String, java.util.TimeZone, java.util.Locale)`
- `org.apache.commons.lang.time.FastDateFormat.FastDateFormat(java.lang.String, java.util.TimeZone, java.util.Locale)`

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).
